channel.title: free range statistics
channel.description: I write about applications of data and analytical techniques like statistical modelling and simulation to real-world situations. I show how to access and use data, and provide examples of analytical products and the code that produced them.

item.title: Pacific island population pyramids (again)
item.description: Population pyramids for Pacific countries, one or two at a time. I use these to highlight contrasts between two coral atoll nations, one of which has free movement to a large, rich country, and one of which doesn't.

item.title: Pacific diaspora
item.description: Some Pacific countries have dramatically more of "their" people living overseas than in the origin country. And some don't.

item.title: The world's biggest 'Pacific' cities
item.description: My best hasty effort at presenting the cities around the world with the most Pacific Islanders resident.

item.title: Visualising income inequality social tables
item.description: Visualising income inequality social tables as a scatter plot rather than a dual axis bar/line plot. I use examples from eighteenth and nineteenth century France, England and Wales drawing on Branko Milanovic's Visions of Inequality 2023 publication.

item.title: New Caledonia's nickel exports
item.description: Accessing data and drawing charts for nickel exports from New Caledonia, and world nickel prices, from 2008 to 2025.

item.title: Net migration in Pacific island countries
item.description: Accessing data and drawing visualisations of net migration for Pacific island countries and territories.

item.title: Visual summaries of population in Pacific islands
item.description: Accessing population data for the Pacific and drawing two visual summaries of its recent and projected growth and absolute size, as used recently in a side event before the Pacific Heads of Planning and Statistics meeting in Wellington.

item.title: Distribution of p-values under the null hypothesis for discrete data
item.description: p-values under the null hypothesis do not necessarily have a uniform distribution.

item.title: Inequality and homicide, within-country and between country
item.description: Countries with higher income or consumption inequality tend to have more homicides per population. But looking at the relationship within each country's data, there does not seem to be a consistent relationship between inequality and homicide rates (that is, when there is a relationship in some countries, on average there is no evidence of such a relationship). This is an interesting multilevel or mixed-effects modelling problem that could easily trip one up.

item.title: Mapping locations related to the Amelia Earhart disappearance
item.description: I draw a map of the Pacific showing the key locations associated with the disappearance of Amelia Earhart and Fred Noonan in 1937.
